result.execSummary:
On one or more charges in this case, Clarence Anthony McKinnie was found not guilty by reason of mental disease or defect. The defendant was found guilty of actually committing the crime(s) charged, but was also found not to be legally responsible under Wis. Stats. 971.165 for committing the crime(s) because of the defendant's mental condition. The legal effect of a finding of not guilty by reason of mental disease or defect is that the court must commit the defendant to the custody of the Department of Health and Family Services.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

judgments.action: Guilty but Not Guilty Due to Mental Disease/Defect

charges.descr: Battery to Public Transit Operator, etc.
charges.dispoDesc: Guilty but Not Guilty Due to Mental Disease/Defect

Defendant Clarence Anthony McKinnie in court with attorney Rosemary Reyes Cuevas.  Defendant Clarence Anthony McKinnie in custody.  Megan Patricia Carmody appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Deputy Court Clerk: dds.

Matter before the Court for Hearing as to Placement (PHASE III of NGI).  Hearing proceeded.  Jeanellyn Cincotta of WCS present.  Parties in receipt of Report dated 1-29-15 authored by Steven J. Genheimer, M.D. and Predisposition Investigation dated 2-12-15 authored by Ms. Cincotta.  Statements made by the state and defense.  The state requests the Court adopt the findings of Dr. Genheimer; defense requests community placement.   The Court previously committed the defendant to the Department of Health Services for a time period not to exceed 18 months.  Argument made by defense as to length of committment; state objects to requested change of time.  The Court orders placement of institutional care.  The DHS is authorized to administer psychotropic medication or treatment to the defendant and shall observe appropriate medical standards in doing so.  Order signed.

Defendant Clarence Anthony McKinnie in court with attorney Rosemary Reyes Cuevas.  Defendant Clarence Anthony McKinnie in custody.  Megan Patricia Carmody appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Deputy Court Clerk: dds.

Defendant prepared to enter change of plea.  Hearing proceeded.  Negotiations set forth by the state.

PHASE I:

AS TO COUNT 1:  The defendant was advised of his constitutional rights and maximum penalties, waived all rights, plead NO CONTEST and was examined as to the plea.  Plea Questionnaire/Waiver of Rights, Addendum to Plea Questionnaire, and Jury Instructions received and filed.  The parties stipulate to the complaint as a factual basis for the plea.  The Court found the defendant guilty and ordered entry of Judgment of Conviction.  Pursuant to Wisconsin Statutes Section 973.176, the Court advised the defendant of the following restrictions:  Firearm possession and Voting.   The Court orders judgment of conviction WITHHELD.

PHASE II:
Parties in court for Phase II of special plea(ngi).  Hearing proceeded.  Parties in receipt of report dated 11-24-14 authored by Dr. John Pankiewicz supporting the special plea.  The state is not challenging the report/findings of Dr. Pankiewicz.  Arguments made by the state and defense.  

The Court Court finds the defendant not guilty by reason of mental disease or defect and orders the defendant committed to the Department of Health Services (DHS) for 18 months with 3 days credit.  The Court makes no order as to medication at this time.  The Court orders predispostion investigation for the purpose of determining commitment placement.  Date selected for Phase III with the parties.  Hearing scheduled for February 23, 2015 at 10:00 am.

Defendant Clarence Anthony McKinnie in court with attorney Rosemary Reyes Cuevas.  Randy P. Sitzberger appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Deputy Court Clerk: dds.

Matter before the Court for Doctor's Report Return.  Hearing proceeded.  Parties in receipt of report dated 11-24-14 authored by Dr. John Pankiewicz supporting the special plea.  There being no challenges to the report the parties select a projected guilty plea date.  Plea hearing scheduled for January 7, 2015 at 01:30 pm.
Report dated 11-24-15 authored by John Pankiewicz, M.D., received and filed.

Court orders defendant TURNED OVER to JUSTICE Point for Supervision.  

No use or possession of controlled substances without a valid prescription  No possession of dangerous weapons or firearms.

Defendant Clarence Anthony McKinnie in court with attorney Rosemary Reyes Cuevas.  Defendant Clarence Anthony McKinnie in custody.  Megan Patricia Carmody appeared for the State of Wisconsin.

Matter before the Court for Review Hearing (as to competency).  Hearing proceeded.  Parties in receipt of reported dated 10-08-14 authored by Mark Phelps, M.D. of the Mendota Mental Health Institute.  There being no challenge to the report the state, defense counsel or defendant, the court found the defendant competent to proceed and ordered the proceedings reinstated.  Defense enters a plea of not guilty and not guilty by reason of mental disease or defect.  Court orders the defendant to be examined by Dr. John Pankiewics of the Wisconsin Forensic Unit pursuant to Wisc. stats. 971.16.  Issue of bail addressed with both counsel.  The Court sets bail at $250.00 CASH with turn over to Justice Point.  Filed, Order for Examination.
  Doctor's Report Return scheduled for December 2, 2014 at 01:30 pm.

Department of Health Services report, received and filed.

Defendant Clarence Anthony McKinnie in court with attorney Rosemary Reyes Cuevas.  Defendant Clarence Anthony McKinnie in custody.  Megan Patricia Carmody appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Deputy Court Clerk: dds.

This matter before the Court for Status conference.  Defendant examined as to competency in case 14CF002162.   Report dated 7-8-14 authored by Dr. Brooke Lundbohm opined the defendant presently not competent to proceed.  No challenges were made from the state, defense, or defendant.  On joint request of the parties the court adopts findings and orders of case 14CF002162.  Therefore as to this case: the court finds the defendant not competent to proceed but likely to become competent within the statutory time period; no objection by defense.   The court orders the proceedings suspended and committed the defendant to the Department of Health Services for an indeterminate term not to exceed 12 months, or the maximum sentence specified for the most serious offense, whichever is less with credit for 21 days.  The Court sets forth medication order with consent of the parties.  Order of Commitment for Treatment (Incompetency) signed and filed.
